awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Computational Methods for Understanding Music, Media, and Minds
awd_abstract_narration:
How can a computer learn to read hidden text in ancient manuscripts? How can a computer be trained to transcribe music audio into music notation or compose a new song? Can a computer system teach a person to better use prosody — the musical pattern of speech – to become a more effective public speaker? These are some of the questions that students will investigate in this Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Rochester. Students will explore an exciting, interdisciplinary research area that combines computer science, electrical engineering, cognitive science, and music. Each student will be mentored by two or more faculty members from the University's schools of engineering, sciences, arts, and music. Other activities of the REU site include workshops on career development; scholarship community colloquiums; graduate school preparation; Python programming for machine learning; and music-focused activities. The goals of this REU are to increase the diversity and broaden the horizons of students engaged in computer science research. The themes of music, digital media, and cognitive science will attract many students from groups under-represented in computer science. The site welcomes students from institutions where opportunities for interdisciplinary research combining computational methods, arts and humanities may be limited. Students who are already majoring in computer science will discover that the research in the field is not limited to traditional engineering applications, but can address questions of art, culture, and human psychology. Students with experience in combining computer science with humanistic research are already in great demand in industry and academia and will help define what it means to be a computer scientist in the 21st century.
 
Students in this REU will engage in interdisciplinary research that combines machine learning, computer audition, music theory, and cognitive science. These disciplines are united by their use of a common set of formal representations and computational methods; in particular, probabilistic models and machine learning. In the research activities, REU students will work on a variety of topics. These include: creating human-computer collaborative music making systems; developing electroencephalogram (EEG) analysis methods to decode musical minds; using machine learning and multispectral imaging to read hidden text in ancient manuscripts; studying how prosody makes a person a convincing public speaker; developing big data techniques to analyze audio-visual scenes; and, exploring connections between human and computer natural language processing. The program is strengthened by the University's recently-founded audio and music engineering program, and the partnership with the Eastman School of Music. Although the major objective of the REU is to encourage students to enter STEM graduate programs, many of the projects can be  expected to lead to novel and publishable research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Layman Abstract:

How can a computer be trained to discover motifs of polyphonic music? What are the neural encodings of musical features when humans listen to music and associate it with any memories? Can we create AI mediated communication technologies that make communication easier between deaf and hard of hearing children and their hearing parents? Can we use computer simulations to identify in what conditions vagueness of natural language evolves? These are some of the questions that students investigated in this Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Rochester over the past 3 years. Each student was mentored by two or more faculty members from the University's schools of engineering, sciences, arts, and music. Other activities of the REU site included workshops on career development including weekly career-talk series; scholarship community colloquiums; graduate school preparation; and Python programming for machine learning offered by the university’s high-performance computing resource center (CIRC). The key outcomes from the award were: 1) Grow participants’ understanding of interdisciplinary research on how the computing field is not limited to traditional engineering applications, but can address questions of music and art, culture, human psychology, and cognition; b) Increase the diversity of students engaged in computer science research. Specifically, have at least 50% of participants be women; have 80% or more from outside the University of Rochester with 50% or more from academic institutions with limited research opportunities in STEM; and at least 33% are from underrepresented minority backgrounds c) Provide a well-rounded training experience to prepare students for graduate education and enriching careers in interdisciplinary areas combining computer science with humanities and social science. Our research results, recruitment statistics, evaluations, and student outcomes demonstrate that we successfully achieved the above goals.

Intellectual Merit: The research projects resulted in notable outcomes including seven research papers presented at international research conferences, undergraduate research symposia, and journals. We also emphasized widespread dissemination of project results. Each student presented a lightning talk on their research. All student participants first gave an oral presentation to peer students and mentors within our REU program in the final week of the session. They then joined other UR REU sites and gave poster presentations and lightning talks in the UR undergrad research symposium [19] [20] organized by the Kearns Center that was also open to the entire campus community. As an example of research output, one undergraduate student contributed to a project on the design of AI-powered Augmented Reality (AR) technologies that facilitate social communicative behaviors without interrupting the social norm of face-to-face interaction. They focused on the deaf and hard of hearing population who communicate with the American Sign Language (ASL). The feedback from students also indicated that we were successful in providing students an interdisciplinary research experience. The pre-REU surveys revealed that less than half of REU students had prior interdisciplinary research exposure to the topics offered by this REU. Multiple students spoke highly of the interdisciplinary research experience. Quoting one of the student participants: “I loved my experience at the University of Rochester. It allowed me to explore options such as potentially working towards a doctorate which I hadn’t thought of before.”

Broadening impacts and participation: Our program consistently attracted over 160 applications each year for the past few sessions with more than 200 in 2023. On average, 42% of applicants were women.  21% were underrepresented minority races, and more than 15% were first generation students. Underrepresented groups (gender, race, disability) represented close to 59% of total applicants to the program. Out of these applications, each session we hosted 10 students from around the country. All the students supported by this grant were from outside the University of Rochester.  70% of the accepted students each year were women. On average, 33% of admitted students were African Americans. 50% of the students in our REU cohort were from non-research universities. The combined representation of underrepresented groups (by race, gender, disability) in our REU participant cohort averaged 87% over the 3 years. We also observed that multiple students in our cohort fell into multiple underrepresented classes, e.g., female African American students attending a non-research college. Our applicant and participant pools were also geographically diverse. The states represented increased from 39 in the 2017-2019 period to 46 in this grant period. Our alumni have been well-placed since finishing our REU program. 16 of the students who graduated from undergraduate programs are pursuing graduate studies at universities throughout the US. 32 are pursuing employment in the computer science industry including major technology companies, finance, and university research laboratories.
